conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, F, coming into contact due to gravity.
Object A is positioned above objects C and D, while object B is positioned above objects E and F.
A and B will drop until they touch the first things that can support them—in this case the tops of C & D and of E & F.
Once contact is made, the normal (support) forces supplied by C–F balance the weight of A and B, stopping their downward motion.
The final state is A resting on C and D, and B resting on E and F.
The only way anything more dramatic would happen is if A or B were so heavy that they tipped one of the smaller blocks over.
Barring the tipping scenario, all objects just come to rest in contact with one another.
